Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Permanent seafloor benchmarks for geodetic measurements of horizontal and vertical plate motion
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI's request funding to increase the longevity of seafloor geodetic measurements by developing and demonstrating an inexpensive, permanent seafloor benchmark. The benchmark will provide a physical tie to the sea floor lasting for decades (perhaps longer) on which geodetic sensors can be repeatedly placed and removed with millimeter resolution. Global coordinates estimated with seafloor geodetic techniques will remain attached to the benchmark allowing for the interchange of sensors as they fail or become obsolete, or for the sensors to be removed and used elsewhere, all the while maintaining a coherent series of positions referenced to the benchmark. The benchmark will be designed to be lowered via a wire to the seafloor with sensors attached. The sensors will be capable of being recalled via an acoustic command sent from a ship to release from the benchmark and freely float to the sea surface for recovery. The duration of the sensor attachment to the benchmark will last from a few days to a few years depending on the specific needs of the experiment. The recovered sensors are then available to be reused at other locations, or again at the same site in the future.

Broader Impacts:

If high accuracy, cheap, campaign-style seafloor geodesy can be developed, the studies that could be done with such a system could transform our knowledge of subduction zones and megathrust earthquakes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The surface of the Earth deforms due to the stresses imposed by moving tectonic plates. The largest deformation is observed near plate boundaries and is associated with stress build up across faults.  On land, the Earth’s deformation is routinely measured using global positioning satellite (GPS) observations with sub-cm accuracy. Most of the world’s largest and most dangerous earthquakes occur on subduction zone megathrust faults such as the Aleutian (Alaska) and Cascadia (US Pacific N.W.) subduction zones. The strain accumulation on these faults occurs mostly offshore, and therefore the deformation of the Earth’s surface associated with these faults also occurs mostly offshore beneath the ocean. Measurements of strain accumulation across these faults is necessary to understand seismic and tsunami hazard in these regions.  The GPS-A method has been developed to measure the location of a fixed position on the seafloor to a precision of better than 1 cm. The fixed point is the center of a set of fixed acoustic transponders on the seafloor. The position and attitude of a temporary surface float is tracked using the global GPS network as it simultaneously interrogates the transponders on the seafloor acoustically, thereby tying the transponders into the global GPS network.  Over time, the position on the seafloor is observed to move due to the deformation of the Earth’s surface caused by strain accumulation across faults and because of movement of the plates.

The goal of this research project was to develop 1) permanent benchmarks for the seafloor for GPS-A (GPS-acoustic) measurements and also 2) techniques to place and remove GPSA transponders from permanent benchmarks using a ROV (remotely operated vehicle). The use of permanent benchmarks makes it possible to extend GPS-A observations indefinitely, or to return a site and easily restart observations following an event such as an earthquake. Previously, because the batteries in the transponders used for GPSA observations had lifetimes of about 5 years, measurements were extended by using a ROV vehicle to photographically navigate in a new transponder array adjacent to the transponders in the original array.

The project tested and deployed a new kind of benchmark that has a top plate with grooves that mate precisely and easily with locating pins on the underside of the transponder. During this project, the Jason ROV was used to manipulate the transponders, demonstrating that the locating pins and grooves reliably and accurately reestablished a replacement transponder onto the benchmark. We also used measurements from the ROV to navigate a new set of transponders (mounted on new permanent benchmarks) with respect to an array of expired transponders deployed fifteen years earlier offshore of Newport OR, achieving an accuracy of better than 1 cm. In the future, reestablishing the GPS-A time series will require only placing a new transponder onto the benchmark using a ROV, avoiding the complicated process of re-navigating the new transponder array against a previous array of expired transponders.

A new waveglider based, GPS navigated, acoustic interrogation platform was subsequently used to survey the new transponders at the site. The waveglider is a wave and solar power platform that can be guided from shore eliminating the need for a ship on site to make GPS-A position observations. The new waveglider survey added a new positional measurement to a series of Juan de Fuca plate motion measurements started fifteen years previously, greatly improving the constraints on Juan de Fuca plate motion velocities.  The acoustic transponders currently on the benchmarks can be retrieved under acoustic command after five years of observations.
